webTitle: Asda withdraws 'mental patient' Halloween costume

fields.standfirst: Thousands react angrily after supermarket website advertises fancy-dress costume that stigmatises mental illness
fields.body:
Asda has apologised and agreed to make a payment to charity after it marketed a Halloween outfit as a "mental patient fancy dress costume".

Images of the costume, now withdrawn from sale, went viral and thousands reacted angrily on Twitter, accusing the supermarket chain of trivialising and stigmatising mental illness.

The product details stated: "Every one will be running away from you in fear in this mental patient fancy dress costume.

"Comprising a torn bloodstained shirt, bloodstained plastic meat cleaver and gory face mask, it's a terrifying Halloween option."

Alastair Campbell, the former spokesman for Tony Blair and a mental health campaigner, tweeted: "What possesses these people?" Asda said it removed the item from its website as soon as it received a complaint. Spokeswoman Leah Spears said: "We received a complaint this morning about the name of a fancy dress outfit. We would never want to offend even one person and so we removed it from our website immediately. It was removed 10 minutes after we received the complaint.

"This was an unacceptable error. We'd like to offer our sincere apologies for the offence it caused. We take our responsibilities very seriously which is why we will make a sizable donation to Mind."

webTitle: Bankers' bonuses: Tory fight against cap is good news for Ed Miliband

fields.standfirst: Treasury announces legal action to stop Brussels limiting bankers' bonuses, even though proposed cap is not draconian
fields.body:
Labour has picked a fight with the energy companies. The Conservatives want to make the world safer for bankers.

For Ed Miliband, the timing could not have been sweeter. One minute news was breaking that Icap, the City firm run by former Conservative party treasurer Michael Spencer, had been fined £55m for manipulating Libor interest rates. The next the Treasury was announcing legal action to prevent Brussels from limiting bankers' bonuses.

Britain's argument is that the bonus cap will make banks more prone to instability. Measures have been put in place already to limit upfront cash bonuses and to ensure they are linked to long-term success. Clamping down on bonuses will result in banks paying bigger basic salaries, which will be more difficult to claw back.

This is a somewhat contrived argument, and not only because the proposed EU-wide cap is not – by normal standards – especially draconian. Bankers would still be able to get a bonus worth 100% of their basic pay, rising to 200% if the payment gets explicit shareholder agreement.

The strength of the UK case can be tested by three simple questions. Did excessive City bonuses contribute to the financial crash? Has enough been done to prevent the bankers blowing up the world a second time? And does the government's determination to prosecute this case have anything to do with the fact that the City provides half the donations to the Conservative party?

To which the answers are: yes, no, and draw your own conclusions.

webTitle: Miliband stands firm in battle over fuel bills plan

fields.bodyText: Shares in two leading energy firms fell sharply on Wednesday as Ed Miliband stood firm over his plan to impose a 20-month energy price freeze if elected in 2015 pending an industry reorganisation designed to inject greater competition and transparency. Centrica, the energy company that responded most aggressively to Miliband's speech on Tuesday announcing the freeze, fell 5.37 % while SSN shares fell 5.76%. Shares in other firms were steady. Energy UK representing the energy sector sent a letter to Miliband seeking an urgent meeting. Earlier on Wednesday, the Labour leader told energy companies: "We can work together on the basis of this price freeze. … Or you can reinforce in the public mind that you are part of the problem not the solution." Miliband also signalled that he was determined not to lose momentum in the wake of the party conference speech, admitting that such a loss had occurred last year in the wake of his One Nation speech. He disclosed that he had asked his party to mount a major doorstep campaign on energy prices, including a film targeted at the hundreds of thousands of swing voters whom the party has identified on Facebook. Labour pointed to YouGov polling showing that the price of energy is the single biggest factor in voters' concerns over living standards. The tracking polling shows that 83% feel energy suppliers maximise profits at expense of customers and 91% expect energy prices to rise over next 12 months. More than half (56%) agree with the statement "energy companies treat people with contempt". The Conservatives said the policy was unravelling after Miliband said he would revisit it if wholesale prices rose sharply during the period of the price freeze. They also said David Cameron had acted on energy prices by requiring that people are offered the lowest tariff. Labour said the coalition had not yet spelled out which consumer groups would receive the lowest tariff offer – almost a year after Cameron made the pledge. Asked how he would respond if energy companies put prices up before his freeze was implemented, Miliband said: "I'm not going to tolerate the energy companies using the fact that there's going to be a price freeze to somehow collude in raising prices before the election. "We are going to make this a meaningful freeze. We will make sure we do that." In his letter, he told the energy companies: "You and I know that the public have lost faith in this market. There is a crisis of confidence. "We face a stark choice. We can work together on the basis of this price freeze to make the market work in the future. Or you can reinforce in the public mind that you are part of the problem not the solution." The Labour leader also started to liken the confrontation with the energy firms to the battle Labour waged against excess bank profits in the late 1990s. He warned: "We will have scare stories from the energy companies, like we had scare stories from the banks – threats, scare stories about regulation. I'm not going to tolerate that. "The Conservative party will support them, but I'm in a different place. I'm standing up for the British people." The response of some City energy experts was scathing, with one claiming that Labour had implicitly abandoned its commitment to the 2020 renewable energy target and probably its 2030 greenhouse gas reduction goals with its plans for an energy price freeze. Peter Atherton, head of utilities research at Liberum Capital, said: "We assume that Labour could not be so staggeringly naive/stupid/misinformed as to believe that an arbitrary price cap is compatible with the threefold (£100bn plus) increase in investment required from next year to hit the renewable target. "Therefore we can only conclude that Labour have now abandoned their environmental targets." He said a "crisis in policy" had been triggered and urged Centrica, the owner of British Gas, to switch its spending away from Britain. Other investment houses such as JP Morgan and Credit Suisse described the Labour moves as detrimental and very concerning. But on Wednesday Angela Knight, chief executive of the power employers group, Energy-UK, struck a more conciliatory note, saying she had written to Miliband asking for a private meeting as soon as possible to discuss the proposed policy changes. "I have said we need to get together and put the facts and issues on the table. We need to share numbers and really get to the bottom of what they are proposing. We need to look at all the choices and all the consequences. The fact is that 20% of a customer bill is transmission and distribution, 20% the green and social levy and another big chunk rising wholesale gas costs over which we have not control. But 'hang on' – we are being told we need to hold the price of a bill down. We need to talk about this."Many of the big six companies have been heavily criticised and fined for a raft of abuses such as doorstep mis-selling but Jo Butlin, the managing director of energy consultancy Utilyx, agreed that they were often unfairly blamed for many rising costs for which they were not responsible. But she admitted they had not helped themselves: "I do not believe that the suppliers are evil profiteers but they have muddied the debate (over rising costs) by scoring lots of own goals."

webTitle: Housing market: Bank of England's set of tools won't prevent a burst bubble

fields.standfirst: Ratio of house prices to earnings is higher than 1988, when the market was on edge of crash that led to record repossessions
fields.body:
Read Mark Carney's lips: there is no new bubble developing in the housing market. Have you got that? A 10% increase in London house prices does not mean the UK is heading for another property boom-bust, and the Bank of England is ready to step in if there is the slightest risk of irrational exuberance setting in.

The statement released by Threadneedle Street following the meeting of the financial policy committee earlier this month shows that the Bank did mull over recent developments in the housing market but decided there was nothing to worry about. "Households' debt servicing costs were low and the ratio of house prices to earnings was at its level of a decade ago," it said.

This is true, but has echoes of the scene in Through the Looking Glass where Humpty Dumpty says a word means "just what I choose it to mean – neither more nor less".

So, yes, it is correct that the ratio of house prices to earnings is back to the levels of a decade ago, but that was a time when the property market was red hot. Seen in a longer historical perspective, the ratio is higher than it was in 1988, when the market was poised on the edge of a crash that led to a doubling of unemployment and record home repossessions. The house price to rent ratio – another indicator monitored by the FPC – is just below where it was in 1988. What's more, the only reason household debt servicing costs are low is that official interest rates are at 0.5%. Were they to rise to even 3%, large numbers of mortgage payers would find themselves in real financial difficulty. That is not likely to occur for some time given the pledge to hold borrowing costs at rock-bottom and to subsidise mortgages. The government's solution to an economic crisis caused by excess private-sector debt is more private-sector debt.

In truth, the only reason that the Bank can conclude that there is no new housing bubble developing is that the old bubble never really went away. Whereas the upswing that began in the mid-1990s began after a brutal real estate shake-out, the current cycle starts with prices already elevated. They will be given a further upward twist by the second phase of the government's misguided Help to Buy scheme when it is launched in the new year.

The Bank says it has a full range of anti-bubble tools in its armoury and will not be afraid to use them. That's nice to know but by the time Threadneedle Street gets round to it, problems with affordability will mean the bubble is collapsing of its own accord anyway.

webTitle: BHP Billiton boss took home £10m in last year

fields.standfirst: Bumper payout for Marius Kloppers included £6m in bonus schemes – and he could yet be in line for another £9.3m
fields.body:
Marius Kloppers, the former boss of mining company BHP Billiton, received $16m (£10m) in his last year at the company and could receive a further £9.3m over the next five years from outstanding bonus awards of shares.

The $16m handed to Kloppers – who officially leaves the world's biggest miner at the end of the month – was largely made up of $10m from long-term bonus schemes that reached maturity.

The annual report shows that in the previous financial year he had cashed in another bonus share scheme worth £4.7m.

The annual report is published before next month's annual meeting, where shareholders have a nominated as a new board member Ian Dunlop – whose election the company is opposing. Shareholders will also vote three times on pay policies – on the remuneration report, a new long-term incentive plan, as well as on any awards of shares to Kloppers' successor, Andrew Mackenzie.

The former chief executive will receive only the 504,000 shares he has outstanding from previous years' bonus awards if the company attains certain performance targets over the next five years.

Kloppers handed the reins to Mackenzie in May and the company's annual report confirmed earlier statements from April that the Glaswegian would be paid 25% a year less than his predecessor.

Kloppers resigned in February after the company reported a 58% fall in profit caused by writedowns in its aluminium business.

Mackenzie, whose salary is $1.7m a year compared with the $2.2m of his predecessor, has now moved to the company's headquarters in Melbourne from the London office where he was based and received a one-off £400,000 in relocation allowances. He also had his signing bonus, handed to him when he joined in 2008 to run one of the divisions, reduced by £3.8m to £4.5m.

For the first time the company used its discretionary powers to reduce payouts from long-term incentive awards, even though the directors had hit the performance criteria by outperforming their rival's total shareholder return. Even so, because BHP Billiton provided a negative return to shareholders, the payouts were cut by 35%.

"This is the first time the committee has exercised its discretion to reduce vesting under the plan. In so doing, it took into account a range of factors, including the negative total shareholder return over the performance period that shareholders have experienced. It also considered the total remuneration of the executives," John Buchanan, chairman of the remuneration committee, said.

webTitle: South African miners win landmark payout against Anglo American

fields.standfirst: First successful case brought by gold miners suffering tuberculosis or silicoses expected to lead to string of settlements
fields.body:
South African miners who developed tuberculosis working in gold mines have won a landmark payout from London-listed mining company Anglo American.

It is the first successful case brought by gold miners suffering tuberculosis or silicosis and is expected to lead to a string of other settlements. Tens of thousands of other affected miners are suing Anglo and other mining companies for hundreds of millions of pounds.

The size of the payout to the 23 former miners has not been disclosed. Since submitting claims in 2004 seven of the miners have died of the condition, which is similar to asbestosis contracted by asbestos workers.

Richard Meeran, a partner at Leigh Day who represents the miners, said the success of the first case "shows the writing is on the wall for mining companies".

"Why would [they] fight any cases now?" he said. "We urge the gold mining companies to establish an industry-wide settlement scheme without delay."

Meeran is representing a further 1,200 former miners in another case against Anglo American. They claim Anglo American South Africa (AASA), a subsidiary of the UK-listed parent, failed to provide protection from dangerous levels of dust created by deep-level gold mining between the 1960s and 1990s.

More than 25,000 former miners and relatives of deceased workers are suing a collection of mining companies. AASA did not admit liability in agreeing to the settlement, and will continue to fight the other cases.

"Agreeing to settle this long-standing litigation is in the best interests of the plaintiffs, their families, Anglo American South Africa and its wider stakeholders," the company said.

Meeran said the number of claimants in the class action – many of whom cannot read and write and signed up to the litigation with a thumb print – could rise to tens of thousands and a potential payout could be worth hundreds of millions.

One of the miners, Daniel Seabata Thakamakau, who started mining gold deep underground when he was 19, said: "While Anglo became rich from the work that we did on their mines, we are now suffering.

"I have no money and I cannot afford to get medical treatment. All we are asking is for the company to provide medical assistance and our fair compensation."

He claims that less than 15 minutes after explosions were set off to open up new areas of the gold mine, he was sent in to dust-filled tunnels without any respiratory protection, which is against industry best practice.

"One day I complained about the amount of dust to the foreman, who called the white boss. He said: 'Do the job or go home.' I continued to work as there was no other option to provide for my family."

Thakamakau, who was paid 1,000 rand (about £100) a month, said he is one of the lucky ones, despite finding it difficult to breathe because his chest is "always burning".

"Three of my five close friends from the mine have already died from the condition," he said. "About 70%-80% of families in my area are headed by women because the men have died, often as a result of mining."

Markedly improved consumer confidence and elevated employment seems to be underpinning retail sales, countering the squeeze on purchasing power currently coming from inflation running well above inflation.

Updated at 12.00pm BST

11.31am BST

UK retail sales are best since June 2012

UK retailers are enjoying their best month's trading since June 2012, with customers flocking to department stores and splashing out on new carpets.

The CBI's monthly distributive trade survey, released a few minutes ago, came in at a balance of +34 for September. That's even better than August's +27. Economists had expected a reading of +24.

Barry Williams, who chairs the CBI survey panel (when not working at Asda), said the sector wasn't "out of the woods" yet, but saw clear signs of recovery. 

It's encouraging to see the high street on the road to recovery, with particularly strong growth from furniture and carpet retailers, department stores and recreational goods.

The balance figure is calculated by taking the percentage of shops who reported a stronger month, and subtracting the percentage of those who said sales were weaker.

Reaction to follow....

11.20am BST

Energy firm shares hit by price freeze pledge

More than one billion pounds has been wiped off the value of Britain's two largest utility firms today, after Labour leader Ed Miliband announced that he would impose a 20-month price freeze on energy bills if he won the next election.

Centrica shares are down almost 4% this morning, knocking some £800m off its market capitalisation (although around one-third of this is because the stock went "ex-dividend" this morning).

SSE's shares have are down 3.5%, which cuts around £500m off its market cap.

My colleague Nick Fletcher has more details: Centrica and SSE slide after Labour price freeze pledge

Yesterday, Miliband put his pledge of an energy price freeze at the heart of his speech at the Labour party conference. Energy firms have attacked the plan, with Centrica's chairman claiming that caps could 'ruin' the industry.

Labour, though, has rubbished the idea that the policy could lead to blackouts. Shadow business spokesman Chuka Umunna told the BBC's Newsnight that claims that the policy would lead to the lights going out were "patently absurd" and "nonsense".

And this morning, Miliband wrote to the energy firms, to ask them to work with him on the issue:

Ed Miliband urges energy firms to co-operate with Labour price freeze

Updated at 11.32am BST

10.58am BST

Three-quarters of Germans want Wolfgang Schäuble to stay on as finance minister in Angela Merkel's next election, according to a poll published today by Forsa.

That poll took place just before Sunday's election, which left Angela Merkel just five seats short of an absolute majority.

Schäuble has now predicted that Merkel will be able to form a government, rather than resorting to fresh elections.

He told Die Zeit that "there will not be new elections" as the other parties have a "basic supply of common sense." (translation via AP)

Schäuble added that he'd prefer " a quick deal to a slow one, given some important European policy decisions we are faced with, for example on banking union."

10.23am BST

Golden Dawn support slides after murder

Support for the neo-nazi Golden Dawn party has fallen sharply since the murder of Pavlos Fyssas last week, according to a new opinion poll released this morning.

Pollsters at Alco found that just 6.8% of people said they supported Golden Dawn, compared with 10.8% in June (Greek reporter Efthimia Efthimiou flags up)

The poll took place between September 20 and 23. Fyssas died in the early hours of September 18, with police swiftly arresting a Golden Dawn supporter who is accused of the stabbing.

However, while support for Golden Dawn has fallen, other parties have not seen a significant rise in total support compared with June. The governing New Democracy's support rose slightly to 21%, and the right-wing Independent Greeks (5%) and communist KKE (4.%) parties also polled higher.

Support for left-wing parties dropped, both for the opposition Syriza party (19.2%) and junior coalition partners Pasok (6%).

Around one third of Greeks didn't express support for any of the parties.

A reminder that there's an anti-fascist rally in Athens tonight....

...and a plug for this piece on Comment Is Free yesterday:

Updated at 10.27am BST

9.55am BST

Bank of England flags up hedge fund worries

The Bank of England's Financial Policy Committee has just pledged to keep a close eye on Britain's housing market, but isn't planning to do anything about concerns that a boom is underway in parts of the country.

The FPC also flagged up concerns that hedge funds could be exposed to losses if long-term interest rates were to rise.

It said a survey of financial firms has found that there was no immediate threat. However, it is worried that those responses "took account of neither more significant stresses nor potential amplification channels through the financial system".

It warned

Borrowers would become more exposed to an increase in interest rates were debt levels to rise and some intermediaries were more affected by a shift in credit spreads.

And on housing, it said:

Mortgage approvals in July were 30% higher than a year earlier and average house prices in August were 5% higher than a year earlier and had risen more in some parts of the country, particularly London.

Nevertheless, activity in the housing market and loan-to-value ratios on new mortgage lending remained below their historic averages. Households’ debt servicing costs were low and the ratio of house prices to earnings was at its level of a decade ago.

In view of that, the Committee judged that it should closely monitor developments in the housing market and banks' underwriting standards. The Committee would be vigilant to potential emerging vulnerabilities.

9.39am BST

Heads-up: we're expecting City broker ICAP to be fined over its part in the Libor scandal this afternoon.

My colleague Jill Treanor reports that the firm could be ordered to pay up to £70m -- and it's possible that US regulators could announce charges against certain individuals too.

More here: Icap staff braced for Libor charges

9.24am BST

Good news from Italy in the last few minutes -- its consumer confidence index has hit its highest level since June 2011, before the eurozone crisis flared up and Silvio Berlusconi's government was brought down.

ITAST reported that Italian consumer confidence rose to 101.1 on its index, up from August's 98.4.

Much better than economists had expected, and based on people reporting that economic conditions right now are better than a month ago. 

However...the survey did show that Italians are less optimistic about future prospects (the expectations subindex fell) and about the employment market.

This table shows the details (apologies if it's too small - The full release is here.)

9.15am BST

Fiscal cliff fears haunt the markets

A weak start in the markets today, with all the main European indices losing ground.

The FTSE 100 has dropped 32 points, or half a percent, to 6538 -- led by cruise ship Carnival, down 7.5%. That's on top of yesterday's 5% slide, after the company warned that it might take three more years to recover from the Costa Concordia accident in which 32 people died.

Asian markets were also down overnight (the Nikkei shed 0.75%).

Fears that America's politicians won't hammer out a deal to raise its debt ceiling are starting to haunt the global markets -- with fastFT blaming the looming fiscal cliff.

• German DAX: down 0.5%

• French CAC: down 0.37%

• Italian FTSE MIB: down 0.36%

• Spanish IBEX: down 0.3%

9.06am BST

More rallies in Greece today

Further protests are expected in Greece today, on the second day of the 48-hour strike called by public workers.

An anti-fascist demonstration has been called for tonight, to demand action against the neoNazi Golden Dawn party -- one week after the death of rapper Pavlos Fyssas (also known as Killahp).

There are also reports in the Greek media that several people are seeking 'witness protection' over Fyssas's death.

Last night, the Greek newspaper Kathimerini reported:

At least five more members of neofascist Golden Dawn are due to be charged in connection with the murder of Pavlos Fyssas last week after police inspected mobile phone records from the night he was stabbed to death by Giorgos Roupakias, who had close links to the far-right party.

8.38am BST

Today's French budget (see also 8.12am) will also include its latest growth forecasts. We're expecting the Paris government to predict virtually no growth for 2013, and just 0.9% for next year.

France's poor performance this year (it only recently emerged from recession), means its deficit for 2013 will be around 3.6% of GDP.

As Reuters puts it:

That puts Paris in line with IMF and European Commission forecasts but what Brussels thinks about the plan as a whole is another matter.

And as France has struggled for decades to bring public spending down, a promise to save €15bn next year could be greeted with some caution.

8.26am BST

Timely... French firms have reported that the business environment has improved this month, but factory bosses aren't sharing the optimism.

France's statistics body, INSEE, reported that overall business sentiment picked up in September, to 94 on its index from 91 last month. Industrial firms, though, are gloomier about their prospects.

Here's the sector-by-sector details:

Updated at 8.33am BST

8.12am BST

French budget due this afternoon

The French government will try to put the country's recession behind it this afternoon when it publishes its budget for 2014, at 3pm local time or 2pm BST.

It's expected to include around €15bn of cuts to government spending, and €3bn of tax rises, along with pledges to stimulate growth and unemployment.

But as AP explains -- some economists already fear the budget may flop: .

The government has promised the measures will re-energize the economy by reducing the role of the state and fostering competition. But economists are split on the merits of cutting spending now.

While the move would in principle be welcome in a country where public spending makes up 57 percent of gross domestic product, it will hurt growth in the short term, just as the country is emerging from recession and with unemployment at 11 percent. The modest tax increases, meanwhile, are eliciting grumbles in France, which already has one of the highest tax burdens in the world.

The budget appears to be Paris' belated effort to fall in line with the rest of Europe's focus on reducing public debts.

The slow approach is typical of Francois Hollande's tenure. The French president is famous for trying not to be famous. His most notable domestic policy so far, the creation of a 75 percent income tax, was rejected by a court and amended so many times that it lost much of its shock value. His reforms have been painstakingly negotiated and have often lost much of their punch by the time they are announced.

And the EU's reaction to the budget will also be interesting. Finance minister Pierre Moscovici will fly to Brussels after he's presented his plans to the French cabinet. Will top eurocrats be satisfied with France, after President Hollande's pension reform plans left them cold.

As Philippe Gudin, chief European economist at Barclays Capital, explained to BusinessWeek:

The retirement reform was disappointing compared with what could have been done -- you almost hesitate to call it a reform

The reaction from Brussels on the budget will set the tone of things to come.

More here: Hollande Faces Europe’s Glass-Half-Empty Test With Budget Plan

7.50am BST

German consumer confidence romps ahead

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

Busy day ahead, with France issuing its 2014 budget, another day of strikes and protest in Greece, and more political action in Germany following last weekend's election.

We can kick off with some economic news – German consumer confidence has hit its highest level since before the financial crisis began.

The monthly survey of German consumers, conducted by GfK, found a "clear upward trend", with Germany's public more willing to spend then ever before. Economic expectations were also up, as the eurozone pulled away from recession.

GfK's index of consumer climate beat expectations by rising to 7.1 for October (the index looks ahead to the next month). That's the highest in six years. September's reading came in at 7.0, revised up from last month's forecast of 6.9.

It's the latest signal of a revival in Europe's largest economy, although those surveyed were less optimistic of rising wages. As GfK put it:

German consumers are expecting the economy to gain momentum again in the coming months. This is reflected in the increase in economic expectations, which are on a clear upward trend. Germans' desire to shop also appears to be unbroken.

In fact, willingness to buy once again improved on the record value of the previous month. However, income expectations declined for the second consecutive time, but continue to be at an extremely high level.

GfK also reported that the eurozone's record low interest rates are making Germans desperate to spend:

Despite the fall in income expectations, consumers are almost euphoric when it comes to their propensity to consume. Now is perceived as a good time to make major purchases.

Europe's debt woes, though, still loom over Germany.

It cannot be ruled out that respondents were influenced by the German parliamentary election for the Bundestag, which had not yet taken place at the time of the survey. Some consumers are perhaps worried that further financial burden will be placed on them, for example, because of the eurozone crisis.

Osborne Takes Legal Action Over EU Bonus Cap Another photo from Greece, showing protestors throwing rocks at riot police, who fired teargas back: Greek police have reportedly fired teargas at demonstrators who threw stones at them during tonight's protests. Reuters reported: Greek police fired teargas at dozens of demonstrators pelting them with stones and bottles in Athens on Wednesday during a protest against the far-right Golden Dawn party, a Reuters witness said. Thousands of Greeks marched to the party's headquarters some 5 km (miles) from the city centre in the biggest show of public anger at the killing of an anti-racism rapper by a Golden Dawn sympathiser. And it looks like the Greek riot police are blocking anti-fascist marchers from getting to Golden Dawn's Athens HQ: Sounds like those Greek demonstrators are taking their message to Golden Dawn's offices: Greece's eKathimerini newspaper is reporting tonight that police probe into the party has widened. Supreme Court deputy prosecutor Charalambos Vourliotis on Wednesday reportedly ordered restrictions to be lifted on the telephone records of officials and lawmakers of the ultra-right Golden Dawn as an investigation into the criminal activities of the party widens. According to sources, judicial authorities who are conducting the investigation in coordination with the National Intelligence Service (EYP) already have evidence that incriminates officials and deputies of the party and could lead to the detention of several suspects on charges of membership of a criminal organization. More here: Probe extends to top echeleons of Golden Dawn Back on Libor, and the Telegraph have pulled together the conversations between brokers and traders during the rate-rigging scandal. Back in the eurozone crisis, a big anti fascist rally is underway in Greece tonight. Those on the scene report a huge turnout, as popular anger over the rise of the Golden Dawn party hits the streets. These photos from Twitter prove it: As I flagged up earlier (see 10.23am), support for the party has slumped since the death of anti-fascist rapper Pavlos Fyssas last week. Elsewhere in the stock market, shares in Centrica and SSE both tumbled over 5% as the row over energy price freezes rumbled on. That wipes around £1bn off Centrica's market capitalisation, and another £800m+ off SSE, as both utility firms suffered from Ed Miliband's pledge to freeze prices for 20 months if he become prime minister in 2015. Centrica has already claimed that price controls could make it uneconomical to run its service. Today's share price falls may reflect predictions that the government will be bounced into its own clampdown. ICAP shares fell this afternoon as the Libor settlement unfolded, finishing down 1.8% at 389p, down 7.3p. They actually rose after the £55m fines were announced -- earlier press reports had suggested it could be as much as £70m. But traders may be reacting to the downbeat trading statement that ICAP also put out, warning that trading eased off in July "followed by a more significant decline in August". Labour MP John Mann has now written to David Cameron, calling on him to hand over the donations he has received from former Conservative party treasurer Michael Spencer. Mann wants the prime minister to hand the money (£4.6m by his count) to Armed Forces charities . They already benefitting from the Libor fines levied on City firms through the "The armed forces covenant (Libor) fund". Mann argued: Michael Spencer’s donations of over £4.6m to the Conservative Party got him access to the Prime Minister at Chequers in 2010. Now his firm ICAP has been fined for fixing the Libor rates. Previous UK Libor fines have been transferred to the Armed Forces Covenant Fund, and then donated to Armed forces charities. In line with this Government policy, today I have called on David Cameron to immediately confirm that he will ensure that all previous donations from Michael Spencer and his company go to Armed forces charities. Mann also tweeted that this is the 'biggest party donor scandal ever' The Labour Party has calculated that ICAP chief executive Michael Spencer had donated almost £5m to the Conservative Party, and it's calling for it to be returned. fastFT has the story: The FT's Jim Pickard and Elizabeth Rigby say Labour is pressing the Tories to pay back donations from Michael Spencer, ICAP's founder, who is a longtime supporter of the party and was even its co-treasurer between 2006 and 2010. A senior Labour source said: "If David Cameron doesn't immediately pay back the £4.8m Michael Spencer gave the Tories, he will be showing yet again that he cares more about standing up for a privileged few than about families and businesses facing a cost of living crisis." The timing of ICAP's reprimand and huge fine at the hands of regulators over Libor manipulation could not have come at a worse time – just three days before the opening of the Conservative party's annual conference. Mr Spencer is close to many senior Tory figures, having donated a total of £4.8m either in person or through his holding company IPGL Ltd. Quite a lively press call, there, particularly when the focus turned onto Michael Spencer himself. But what are the key points? • ICAP didn't know that Libor rigging was happening on its watch until 2011. Spencer explained that the bank only realised what was occuring when regulators came and told them, after a probe at UBS. That suggests a major failure of internal controls -- the rigging had begun five years earlier. • Senior managers are being hit in the pocket. Spencer said that compensation would be "impacted considerably" <- City speak for smaller bonuses. However, Spencer didn't say that he will personally hand back any bonus for 2013. • City culture is back in the dock. Another Libor scandal means another collection of embarrassing messages, painting a grim picture of kickbacks and arrogance. Michael Spencer insisted that he, and the vast majority of staff, are shocked by the affair and determined to avoid a repeat. But today's headlines will be a reminder of just how badly things went wrong. • Spencer is squarely in the spotlight. As a species, chief executives don't like being criticised. But Spencer founded ICAP, so must be responsible for the culture of the firm. He played the bad apple card- arguing that the man at the top can't be help responsible for every failing within a large company. But the fact he was also acting as Conservative Party Treasurer while a small group of his employees were rigging the yen Libor rate must hurt. • The political angle. Spencer was perfectly civil when he suggested reporters check the official records to find his donations to the Conservatives. But I don't think he liked it being raised, at all. There's going to be pressure on David Cameron over the money donated over the years... Final question -- apparently the Labour Party has already issued a statement, saying that ICAP's Libor fine is an embarrassment to the government, because Michael Spencer has donated money in the past. Does he have any view on the suggestion that the Conservatives should repay the money? And is he still a Conservative Party donor? Spencer says that he can't speak for David Cameron, or other senior party members. And his donations are a matter of public record -- you'll have to check the details yourself. And that's the end of the press call. Spencer also concedes that it was a mistake for the trading desk at the heart of the Yen Libor rigging to not be audited during the time the activities took place. ICAP has beefed up its compliance department since -- it's now 50-people strong, and the firm is spending £17m per year on it. Spencer fields another question about his decision not to resign. He insists that he is committed to avoid any repeat of the Libor scandal, saying: I bear this responsibly very very profoundly. And asked about the culture at ICAP, he insists "I promise I care a hell of a lot", and insisting that the vast majority of people at the company are "bitterly angry" and "shocked" about what happened. Why is Michael Spencer different from Barclays' Bob Diamond, or RBS's John Hourican, who both resigned over their banks' involvement in the Libor scandal, asks Harry Wilson of the Telegraph. Spencer says he doesn't believe this case is comparable. He adds that ICAP have spoken to its top shareholders today -- the implication being that he still has their support. Juliet Samuel of The Times asks why ICAP has not clawed back bonuses from those at the heart of the scandal. Spencer explains the main reason is that the three people at the heart of the Libor-rigging are now being prosecuted by the DoJ. And the bad apple line come up -- this involved more than a few people, across several banks. Spencer says that " like you, I share a real sense of disappointment over this." Regulators are, rightly, taking this very seriously. He welcomes that, and says he believes that the markets at the heart of this will be "cleaner, more professional....and fit for purpose". Does Spencer regret handing the Labour Party a weapon to beat the government with, asks the FT's Jonathan Guthrie. Spencer declines to answer it. Is ICAP providing any financial help to the traders who have been dismissed? No, Spencer replies. Spencer also reveals that mobile phones have been banned on the ICAP trading floor, to prevent a repeat fo the Libor scandal. Next question - has Michael Spencer considered his position? He says he's considered "many things" but considered that it would be "very dangerous" if the head is responsible for activity he didn't know about, especially in a big company. But isn't this an issue of company culture? Spencer replies that it's a "rotten apple" issue, and believes he is the best man to lead the company. My colleague Jill Treanor asks Michael Spencer whether the fact he was working as Conservative party treasurer was a factor in the libor rate-rigging. He denies it. Spencer explains that he didn't know any of the people involved this episode, and "I don't believe that if I'd been here more I would have picked it up." Spencer also argues that very few people would have even thought there could be a "concert party effort" to manipulate Libor. At the time, many people thought it was unmanipulatable. Spencer also denies suggesting that Libor wasn't a big deal, but says the firm didn't know about it until the regulators discovered problems at UBS. And Duncan Wales reveals that ICAP has probed 12 million documents, and is examining another 40 million, in its search for evidence. The FT asks what ICAP have done to clean up its systems, and why they weren't strong enough at the time. Michael Spencer replies that while ICAP had instigated tough systems, it did not " invisige a very carefully concealed collaboration between traders and a banker". In the end, every firm is at risk to "rogue conduct". David Enrich of the Wall Street Journal questions how senior managers could not be culpable, given that the financial inducements paid to UBS traders was signed off by certain senior managers. Duncan Wales, ICAP's group general counsel, replies that there was a difference between what the managers knew was going on, and what the individuals knew was going on. Wales also explains that ICAP's internal procedures don't allow individual traders to sign off such payments to other banks, in an attempt to stop malpractice. How could the traders sound so relaxed about fixing Libor? Spencer replies that people showed a "cavalier disregard" for the rules, in what was a "profoundly regrettable period". Questions. City AM goes first. Will Michael Spencer lose out personally? "The answer is yes", Spencer replies. Although he doesn't set his own bonus, there is no doubt that the compensation for senior managers, and those in the relevant trading divisions, will be affected Our compensation will be impacted considerably. In conclusion, Spencer says, this has been a difficult period for the company, but one we can move on from. We will harden our compliance, and continue to offer clients the service they expect. Michael Spencer, CEO of ICAP, is hosting the call with senior managers. He's starting by outlining today's news -- basically repeating the statement announced earlier. Spencer says he deeply regrets the actions of those responsible, calling it 'deeply wrong' . He also takes some comfort that senior managers have not been implicated. ICAP is holding a press call to discuss its settlement with the FCA and the CFTC over Libor. It's just starting.... He has chased them and cannot understand their motives .Its not even the rbs and [Bank D’s] of the world that fcked us he has no influence on Bank C, would have spoken to [Bank H] but the guy is pretty stuborn and reckons he's always right. That includes the revelation that one broker involved in the scheme received bonus payments of £5,000 per quarter, worth a total of £50,000. Here's a flavour: i. On 18 April 2007, Broker 3 emailed Broker 2, stating: “With [UBS] how much does [Trader A] appreciate the yen libor scoop? It seems to me that he has all his glory etc and u guys get his support in other things. I get the drib and drabs.” In that email, Broker 3 then requested “some form of performance bonus per quarter from your . . . bonus pool to me for the libor service.” ii. The following day, Broker 3 sent another email to Broker 2 threatening “LIBORS NO MORE,” if he did not receive sufficient compensation. Broker 3 added that “As far as I was concerned [Trader A] was paying for the libor assist for my assistance” and that were he not to be compensated properly, there would be “no more mr libor.” Because Brokers 1 and 2 believed that Broker 3 was critical to the success of the scheme, they agreed (with Trader A’s support) to pay him a “LIBOR services” bonus or “fixing service” bonus as a reward. The bonus money was derived from UBS’s brokerage commission and was allocated to Broker 3 out of the JPY Derivatives Desk’s bonus pool. For much of that time, chief executive Michael Spencer was also serving as Conservative party treasurer, as Channel 4's Faisal Islam flags up: The DoJ claims that Colin Goodman, who worked as a cash broker at ICAP’s London office, was known as "Lord Libor" by colleagues, and also used the term himself. They are Darrell Read, who resides in New Zealand, and Daniel Wilkinson and Colin Goodman, both of England, were charged with conspiracy to commit wire fraud and two counts of wire fraud in a criminal complaint unsealed in Manhattan federal court earlier today. Hammond, deputy assistant attorney general for the Antitrust Division’s criminal enforcement program, said: In exchange for bigger bonus checks, the three defendants undermined financial markets around the world by compromising the integrity of globally used interest rate benchmarks. The Department continues to demonstrate its commitment to protecting the interest of American citizens in free and fair financial markets. Restoring trust in the industry starts with rooting out and recognising bad practice. True change will however only be achieved when all in the financial services industry accept and deliver on their responsibility to ensure that markets operate with integrity. This is our fourth penalty in relation to LIBOR and our investigations continue. The lessons however go far wider than LIBOR and we will take a very dim view of those who do not learn them. It also reports that one broker received "corrupt bonus payments (at the instigation of one manager)" as a reward for his assistance in manipulating the Japanese Libor rate. The FCA found that UBS traders made at least 330 written requests to brokers at ICAP Europe Limited for inappropriate submissions, along with an unknown number of "oral requests". ICAP, the City brokerage firm, has just announced that it's been fined a total of £55m for its role in the Libor scandal. The fine consists of a £14m payment to the UK's Financial Conduct Authority, and the rest to America's CFTC. In another key development, three former executives have been charged by the Department of Justice. Their conduct contravenes all that ICAP stands for. As soon as their actions came to light, we provided assistance to regulators in the U.S. and U.K. to understand what had happened. None of the three individuals at the centre of the activity remains with the firm. Others are either no longer with the company or are being disciplined. More to follow Will the Ukraine be the next country to be dragged into the financial crisis? Its government bonds hit record lows on Tuesday, amid steady selling from anxious bond investors. The cost of insuring its debt against default also spiked yesterday, reflecting fears over liquidity. And the Ukrainian hryvnia has weakened steadily against the US dollar. As I type, Fitch are talking about Ukraine risks... FITCH ANALYST SAYS ANY RAPID FALL IN UKRAINE FX RESERVES, LACK OF CLEAR DEBT REFINANCING POLICY WOULD "WEIGH ON" CURRENT B RATING So, now's a good time to check out this piece in the Wall Street Journal, by Serena Ruffoni Ukraine's Troubles Hit Bonds Economists are warning that the French government faces a real struggle to drag its economy forwards, based on today's 2014 budget. Marc Touati, economist at French business consultancy ACDEFI, is concerned that Francois Hollande's government is raising taxes by €3bn, with the burden falling on households. He said: The tax on households will hurt spending power a little more and we risk having a bad surprise from consumer spending in 2014 Taxes need to be cut on both business and consumers. As explained earlier, today's budget does not increase the total tax burden on companies -- even though Hollande's famous 75% tax on those earning over €1,000,000 per year will fall on employers. Julien Manceaux, economist at ING Bank in Brussels, said: They are betting on favoring businesses to create jobs and then consumer spending in the longer term. (quotes via the WSJ) Meanwhile Jacob Kirkegaard, senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington, argues that France lacks the motivation to really reform its economy, because it has avoided the worst effects of the eurozone crisis (such as the deep recessions and record jobless totals seen in Southern Europe) There's never going to be a hard landing. ... It's going to be a gradual underperformance. France's fiscal watchdog has checked the numbers in today's budget (see last post), and says the growth forecasts are plausible. However, the structural deficit targets may not be. Here's the key quote (via Reuters) The High Council considers that the structural deficit target for 2014 is optimistic because of a risk of overestimating revenues and of the fragility of forecasts in terms of spending. It's official: France is raising taxes and cutting government spending, in an attempt to lower its deficit next year. As predicted, next year's budget will include €15bn of cuts to public spending, and €3bn from tax rises and a clampdown on tax evasion. That's on top of a planned increase in the sales tax, that should being in another €6bn Paris is also lowering the tax burden on firms, in a bit to boost competitiveness and get the French economy growing faster. And Francois Hollande's famous super-tax on big earners is finally here, Reuters explains: The government announced a change in corporate tax policy, by scrapping an annual flat tax on top of other levies and introducing a new one based on operating profits.It will, as planned, slap a 75-percent tax on salaries exceeding 1 million euros per year, a rate that includes social contributions. The tax will be levied on firms rather than the employees themselves. French firms are also getting €10bn in tax breaks meant to boost competiveness, the burden will be smaller. But details of the 2014 budget [released earlier than suggested earlier] also show that the French national debt will hit 95.1% of gross domestic product, up from 93.4% this year. That means France's debt servicing costs are expected to rise to €46.7bn, from €45bn in 2013. And, as expected, the sums are based on projected growth of 0.9% in 2014, and just 0.1% this year. France's total deficit will be 4.1% of GDP this year, and forecast to fall to 3.6% in 2014. It then hits the 3% target mandated by the EU in 2015 - two year's late. More to follow Overnight, the former head of the International Monetary Fund's mission to Ireland has warned that any more austerity measures might cripple the Republic's economy for years to come. From Dublin, Henry McDonald reports: Professor Ashoka Mody said Ireland needed a “new jolt of growth” especially since the Republic officially at least emerged from recession last week. Despite turning the corner out of recession Professor Mody pointed out that growth in Ireland over the last 12 months had been very disappointing, “notwithstanding some ups and downs of an episodic nature.” “I’m afraid we are already five years into the crisis and with households continuing to try to catch up with their lost wealth, they are not spending ... if the Government and households are both not spending, it’s not a surprise that the economy is not growing,” he told RTÉ’s Prime Time television programme last night. His warning is apposite given that the Fine Gael-Labour coalition is currently drawing up its battle plans for Budget 2014, which will see millions of euros in more cutbacks in the Republic's huge public sector as the state drives down the national deficit. Meanwhile in the relatively successful IT private sector there is more good news today with Twitter announcing the creation of an extra 100 jobs to its Irish operation. The extra jobs will double the size of the global social network's Dublin office, Twitter said. The investment in more staff is being seen as a major vote of confidence in Twitter's Irish based business. It comes as Facebook, which employs 450 people in Dublin, is also considering increasing its staff numbers in Ireland. Today's strong UK retail sales data (see last post) has bolstered hopes that Britain's economic recovery is continuing. Every single furniture and carpet store surveyed reported higher sales than a year ago, which is the best performance since 1996. That's probably due to increased activity in the housing market as more people move house. Richard Lowe, head of retail & Wholesale at Barclays, said: Retail sales have grown for the third month running, and today’s strong figures will no doubt provide a fillip for the high street. Retailers will now be hoping for more seasonal weather to help sales of new autumn/winter collections and for consumer confidence to tick up as we head towards the crucial Christmas trading period. And here's Howard Archer of IHS's Global Insight: It looks possible that the economy could have grown by close to 1.0% quarter-on-quarter in the third quarter. Markedly improved consumer confidence and elevated employment seems to be underpinning retail sales, countering the squeeze on purchasing power currently coming from inflation running well above inflation. UK retailers are enjoying their best month's trading since June 2012, with customers flocking to department stores and splashing out on new carpets. The CBI's monthly distributive trade survey, released a few minutes ago, came in at a balance of +34 for September. That's even better than August's +27. Economists had expected a reading of +24. Barry Williams, who chairs the CBI survey panel (when not working at Asda), said the sector wasn't "out of the woods" yet, but saw clear signs of recovery. It's encouraging to see the high street on the road to recovery, with particularly strong growth from furniture and carpet retailers, department stores and recreational goods. The balance figure is calculated by taking the percentage of shops who reported a stronger month, and subtracting the percentage of those who said sales were weaker. Reaction to follow.... More than one billion pounds has been wiped off the value of Britain's two largest utility firms today, after Labour leader Ed Miliband announced that he would impose a 20-month price freeze on energy bills if he won the next election. Centrica shares are down almost 4% this morning, knocking some £800m off its market capitalisation (although around one-third of this is because the stock went "ex-dividend" this morning). SSE's shares have are down 3.5%, which cuts around £500m off its market cap. My colleague Nick Fletcher has more details: Centrica and SSE slide after Labour price freeze pledge Yesterday, Miliband put his pledge of an energy price freeze at the heart of his speech at the Labour party conference. Energy firms have attacked the plan, with Centrica's chairman claiming that caps could 'ruin' the industry. Labour, though, has rubbished the idea that the policy could lead to blackouts. Shadow business spokesman Chuka Umunna told the BBC's Newsnight that claims that the policy would lead to the lights going out were "patently absurd" and "nonsense". And this morning, Miliband wrote to the energy firms, to ask them to work with him on the issue: Ed Miliband urges energy firms to co-operate with Labour price freeze Three-quarters of Germans want Wolfgang Schäuble to stay on as finance minister in Angela Merkel's next election, according to a poll published today by Forsa. That poll took place just before Sunday's election, which left Angela Merkel just five seats short of an absolute majority. Schäuble has now predicted that Merkel will be able to form a government, rather than resorting to fresh elections. He told Die Zeit that "there will not be new elections" as the other parties have a "basic supply of common sense." (translation via AP) Schäuble added that he'd prefer " a quick deal to a slow one, given some important European policy decisions we are faced with, for example on banking union." Support for the neo-nazi Golden Dawn party has fallen sharply since the murder of Pavlos Fyssas last week, according to a new opinion poll released this morning. Pollsters at Alco found that just 6.8% of people said they supported Golden Dawn, compared with 10.8% in June (Greek reporter Efthimia Efthimiou flags up) The poll took place between September 20 and 23. Fyssas died in the early hours of September 18, with police swiftly arresting a Golden Dawn supporter who is accused of the stabbing. However, while support for Golden Dawn has fallen, other parties have not seen a significant rise in total support compared with June. The governing New Democracy's support rose slightly to 21%, and the right-wing Independent Greeks (5%) and communist KKE (4.%) parties also polled higher. Support for left-wing parties dropped, both for the opposition Syriza party (19.2%) and junior coalition partners Pasok (6%). Around one third of Greeks didn't express support for any of the parties. A reminder that there's an anti-fascist rally in Athens tonight.... ...and a plug for this piece on Comment Is Free yesterday: The Bank of England's Financial Policy Committee has just pledged to keep a close eye on Britain's housing market, but isn't planning to do anything about concerns that a boom is underway in parts of the country. The FPC also flagged up concerns that hedge funds could be exposed to losses if long-term interest rates were to rise. It said a survey of financial firms has found that there was no immediate threat. However, it is worried that those responses "took account of neither more significant stresses nor potential amplification channels through the financial system". It warned Borrowers would become more exposed to an increase in interest rates were debt levels to rise and some intermediaries were more affected by a shift in credit spreads. And on housing, it said: Mortgage approvals in July were 30% higher than a year earlier and average house prices in August were 5% higher than a year earlier and had risen more in some parts of the country, particularly London. Nevertheless, activity in the housing market and loan-to-value ratios on new mortgage lending remained below their historic averages. Households’ debt servicing costs were low and the ratio of house prices to earnings was at its level of a decade ago. In view of that, the Committee judged that it should closely monitor developments in the housing market and banks' underwriting standards. The Committee would be vigilant to potential emerging vulnerabilities. Heads-up: we're expecting City broker ICAP to be fined over its part in the Libor scandal this afternoon. My colleague Jill Treanor reports that the firm could be ordered to pay up to £70m -- and it's possible that US regulators could announce charges against certain individuals too. More here: Icap staff braced for Libor charges Good news from Italy in the last few minutes -- its consumer confidence index has hit its highest level since June 2011, before the eurozone crisis flared up and Silvio Berlusconi's government was brought down. ITAST reported that Italian consumer confidence rose to 101.1 on its index, up from August's 98.4. Much better than economists had expected, and based on people reporting that economic conditions right now are better than a month ago. However...the survey did show that Italians are less optimistic about future prospects (the expectations subindex fell) and about the employment market. This table shows the details (apologies if it's too small - The full release is here.) A weak start in the markets today, with all the main European indices losing ground. The FTSE 100 has dropped 32 points, or half a percent, to 6538 -- led by cruise ship Carnival, down 7.5%. That's on top of yesterday's 5% slide, after the company warned that it might take three more years to recover from the Costa Concordia accident in which 32 people died. Asian markets were also down overnight (the Nikkei shed 0.75%). Fears that America's politicians won't hammer out a deal to raise its debt ceiling are starting to haunt the global markets -- with fastFT blaming the looming fiscal cliff. • German DAX: down 0.5% • French CAC: down 0.37% • Italian FTSE MIB: down 0.36% • Spanish IBEX: down 0.3% Further protests are expected in Greece today, on the second day of the 48-hour strike called by public workers. An anti-fascist demonstration has been called for tonight, to demand action against the neoNazi Golden Dawn party -- one week after the death of rapper Pavlos Fyssas (also known as Killahp). There are also reports in the Greek media that several people are seeking 'witness protection' over Fyssas's death. Last night, the Greek newspaper Kathimerini reported: At least five more members of neofascist Golden Dawn are due to be charged in connection with the murder of Pavlos Fyssas last week after police inspected mobile phone records from the night he was stabbed to death by Giorgos Roupakias, who had close links to the far-right party. Today's French budget (see also 8.12am) will also include its latest growth forecasts. We're expecting the Paris government to predict virtually no growth for 2013, and just 0.9% for next year. France's poor performance this year (it only recently emerged from recession), means its deficit for 2013 will be around 3.6% of GDP. As Reuters puts it: That puts Paris in line with IMF and European Commission forecasts but what Brussels thinks about the plan as a whole is another matter. And as France has struggled for decades to bring public spending down, a promise to save €15bn next year could be greeted with some caution. Timely... French firms have reported that the business environment has improved this month, but factory bosses aren't sharing the optimism. France's statistics body, INSEE, reported that overall business sentiment picked up in September, to 94 on its index from 91 last month. Industrial firms, though, are gloomier about their prospects. Here's the sector-by-sector details: The French government will try to put the country's recession behind it this afternoon when it publishes its budget for 2014, at 3pm local time or 2pm BST. It's expected to include around €15bn of cuts to government spending, and €3bn of tax rises, along with pledges to stimulate growth and unemployment. But as AP explains -- some economists already fear the budget may flop: . The government has promised the measures will re-energize the economy by reducing the role of the state and fostering competition. But economists are split on the merits of cutting spending now. While the move would in principle be welcome in a country where public spending makes up 57 percent of gross domestic product, it will hurt growth in the short term, just as the country is emerging from recession and with unemployment at 11 percent. The modest tax increases, meanwhile, are eliciting grumbles in France, which already has one of the highest tax burdens in the world. The budget appears to be Paris' belated effort to fall in line with the rest of Europe's focus on reducing public debts. The slow approach is typical of Francois Hollande's tenure. The French president is famous for trying not to be famous. His most notable domestic policy so far, the creation of a 75 percent income tax, was rejected by a court and amended so many times that it lost much of its shock value. His reforms have been painstakingly negotiated and have often lost much of their punch by the time they are announced. And the EU's reaction to the budget will also be interesting. Finance minister Pierre Moscovici will fly to Brussels after he's presented his plans to the French cabinet. Will top eurocrats be satisfied with France, after President Hollande's pension reform plans left them cold. As Philippe Gudin, chief European economist at Barclays Capital, explained to BusinessWeek: The retirement reform was disappointing compared with what could have been done -- you almost hesitate to call it a reform The reaction from Brussels on the budget will set the tone of things to come. More here: Hollande Faces Europe’s Glass-Half-Empty Test With Budget Plan Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. Busy day ahead, with France issuing its 2014 budget, another day of strikes and protest in Greece, and more political action in Germany following last weekend's election. We can kick off with some economic news – German consumer confidence has hit its highest level since before the financial crisis began. The monthly survey of German consumers, conducted by GfK, found a "clear upward trend", with Germany's public more willing to spend then ever before. Economic expectations were also up, as the eurozone pulled away from recession. GfK's index of consumer climate beat expectations by rising to 7.1 for October (the index looks ahead to the next month). That's the highest in six years. September's reading came in at 7.0, revised up from last month's forecast of 6.9. It's the latest signal of a revival in Europe's largest economy, although those surveyed were less optimistic of rising wages. As GfK put it: German consumers are expecting the economy to gain momentum again in the coming months. This is reflected in the increase in economic expectations, which are on a clear upward trend. Germans' desire to shop also appears to be unbroken. In fact, willingness to buy once again improved on the record value of the previous month. However, income expectations declined for the second consecutive time, but continue to be at an extremely high level. GfK also reported that the eurozone's record low interest rates are making Germans desperate to spend: Despite the fall in income expectations, consumers are almost euphoric when it comes to their propensity to consume. Now is perceived as a good time to make major purchases. Europe's debt woes, though, still loom over Germany. It cannot be ruled out that respondents were influenced by the German parliamentary election for the Bundestag, which had not yet taken place at the time of the survey. Some consumers are perhaps worried that further financial burden will be placed on them, for example, because of the eurozone crisis. And here's the details of this month's survey. I'll be tracking all the developments through the day, as usual....

webTitle: Homebase aims to take on specialists in decorating and design

fields.standfirst: Home and gardens store admits offering new services won't be hugely profitable, but will win it customer loyalty
fields.body:
Never mind do it yourself, Homebase says nearly a third of its future tradecould come from offering services to shoppers – starting with home decorating and design.

Less than 15% of the home and gardens store's trade currently comes from offering services such as kitchen and bathroom installation, but the company is using a mix of contractors and retrained store staff to start offering home design, decorating and flooring installation.

Paul Loft, the managing director of Homebase, which is part of Home Retail Group, owner of Argos, admitted that offering services was not highly profitable, but said: "We get to sell product and win customer loyalty." He added: "We are taking on the specialists."

Homebase is trying to differentiate itself from rivals such as B&Q and Wickes by offering a more department store-like atmosphere. It has refurbished 15 stores at a cost of £1m each over the past year, putting in concessions for more up-market brands such as Laura Ashley and Habitat, which HRG now owns. Those stores have seen sales lift 20%, offsetting higher costs in terms of staff and shop fittings, so Loft said he wanted to step up the number of refurbishments next year.

There are currently nine mini Habitat stores within Homebase outlets. Loft wants to expand this to up to 100 stores over time.

webTitle: BAE Systems flies on Typhoon order hopes, as FTSE 100 drifts lower

fields.standfirst: Leading shares hit by investor concerns on US budget, while energy companies fall on Labour price freeze pledge
fields.body:
BAE Systems was flying high on hopes of new orders for its Typhoon aircraft.

UBS issued a buy note and raised its price target from 450p to 490p on talk of a UAE contract. Analyst Charles Armitage said:

We understand that the bid for up to 60 Typhoons (plus unmanned aerial vehicles and technology sharing) has been submitted – the timing of a decision is always very difficult to forecast, but we estimate a win could be worth about 30p per share on a net present value basis – we have put a 50% (win) on this to give 15p additional value to our price target.

UBS also believed that a long awaited deal relating to extra payment for the first tranche of Typhoons supplied to Saudi Arabia - due in part to changing requirements - could be signed in the second half:

Given that this was first hoped for before the end of 2011 and then before the end of 2012, we believe that signature must reduce the risk.
BAE Systems is unique in our defence coverage in that it has a large enough growth market in the middle east (mainly Saudi Arabia) to offset the decline in the US defence.

The company closed 10.4p higher at 461.3p, one of the biggest risers in a downbeat FTSE 100. The leading index lost 19.93 points to 6551.53, as investors remained cautious as the US budget impasse continuing, with the prospect of the country's government shutting down next month.

Labour's pledge to freeze energy prices - part of Ed Miliband's speech on Tuesday - had a belated effect on gas and electricity companies. SSE fell 91p to £14.89, a 5.7% decline which wiped nearly £900m off its market capitalisation. British Gas-owner Centrica closed 21.1p lower at 375.6p, losing nearly £1bn off its valuation. Some 4.9p of Centrica's fall was due to its shares going ex-dividend.

The day's biggest faller in the FTSE 100 was Carnival. The cruise company slumped another 152p to £21.06 as analysts downgraded after Tuesday's disappointing third quarter results and outlook.

Accountancy software specialist Sage slipped 11.6p to 335.5p on growing competition fears.

New Zealand based rival Xero was in London this week to outline its plans for the UK accounting software market, Sage's key strength. Credit Suisse issued an underperform note and said:

Three pieces of news this week serve as a useful reminder that Sage remains at risk from cloud providers. At the large-end, Netsuite is actively looking to take market share, at the smaller end we continue to see Sage as a laggard to more innovative competitors such as Xero, while Intuit has reiterated guidance for 10%-12% growth, materially faster than the 3%-4% growth that is expected at Sage.

Tesco dropped 13.1p to 360.9p after JP Morgan downgraded from neutral to underweight:

We believe the UK food retailing industry has structural problems, and think Tesco will be most impacted. The discounters (Aldi, Lidl) are disrupting the price/range architecture that the big four used for two decades, the customer is demanding a simplified product range, and there is a need for reduced mid-tier pricing. With Tesco's initiatives having had limited success, weak like-for-likes, and margins persistently above peers', we think Tesco is more likely to go through a painful rebasing of pricing and the gross margin (synonymous to a profit warning).

Heading in the other direction was precious metals miner Fresnillo, up 35p at £10.06 as bargain hunters moved in after recent falls.

Workspace, which provides office space for growing companies, jumped 18.7p to 433.4p after it won planning permission to redevelop its Poplar Business Park in Canary Wharf. John Cahill at Investec said:

We consider this deal to be typical of Workspace's ability to drive its refurbishment and redevelopment programme without jeopardising the strong income growth in the investment portfolio. This deal, alongside others in the pipeline, will form the basis for higher returns to shareholders in the medium- to long-term.

webTitle: Superyacht makers at Monaco Yacht Show buoyant as demand grows

fields.standfirst: Rich put recession far behind them as UK manufacturers of luxury yachts report record revenues of £460m
fields.body:
Ed Miliband's assertion that the rising tide of economic fortune used to lift all boats, but now only seems to lift yachts, would certainly seem to be borne out by the Monaco Yacht Show. The show, which has just begun, boasts Europe's largest collection of superyachts. At the show the Labour leader would find that demand is once again surging for the ultimate billionaire's plaything, ranging from an entry-level 30 metre-long boat costing around £10m, to gigantic vessels with 90-strong crews that are effectively private cruise liners.

The UK superyacht industry – a superyacht is more than 24 metres long – has reported record revenues of £460m, up 4% on last year, as more of their traditional customers in the US, Russia and the Middle East place orders for these custom-built, floating palaces.

In a survey of 138 companies in the superyacht industry, half reported an increased workload compared to a year ago, while only 19% – a smaller proportion than last year – said their workload had gone down.

The companies, which include yacht builders, designers and legal firms, are also in their most upbeat mood since before the economic crash, with 69% rating their prospects for the year ahead as "good or excellent", compared with 51% last year.

Tom Chant of Superyacht UK said the industry was in a buoyant mood, but profits had not yet returned to the 2007 pre-recession era.

"That was a particular bubble that has definitely burst." Current growth was more stable, he said. "The people who are coming into the market do have the money, they are not borrowing on banks who have borrowed on other things. The buyers that are coming in are good solid buyers who are there for the long-term."

The UK industry, which employs 3,550 people, has further room to grow. "There are more yards that could build yachts, than there are yachts with orders," Chant added.

The revival is supported by another industry survey from yachtmaker Camper & Nicholsons, which reported a 37% jump in yacht sales in the first half of the year to around 200 boats. However, the overall value of the market remained flat at $1bn (£620m), as industry figures are easily skewed by a few hyper-extravagant purchases.

The biggest market for superyachts remains the US, followed by Russia and the Middle East. China's super-rich have yet to develop much of an interest, despite the recent sale of Sunseeker International to the country's Dalian Wanda group. In Monaco "there is lots of talk about the potential of China, but it is just potential," said Chant.

The downturn slowed yacht buyers' appetite for extra-large yachts, with demand for vessels greater than 50 metres falling in 2011 and 2012, according to Camper & Nicholsons. But there are signs that it may be returning.

On the drawing board of the Hampshire-based firm Dubois are plans for a giant sloop, 101 metres long with a 125-metre mast that would dwarf both Big Ben's Elizabeth Tower and the Statue of Liberty.

webTitle: Punch Taverns sees profits fall by a quarter

fields.standfirst: Company hopes to begin financial restructuring in the fourth quarter after discussions with bondholders
fields.body:
Punch Taverns, the debt-laden pubs group, saw profits fall by almost a quarter last year as it cut the size of its estate.

Profits fell from £64m to £49m, and the company said it had disposed of 433 pubs for £149m, bringing its total to around 4,000. Another 1,100 non-core sites are expected to be sold over the next four years, according to analysts at Numis.

It hopes to reach agreement with bondholders on restructuring its finances in the fourth quarter of this year, but after an earlier proposal was rejected in June, it admitted the process had taken longer than expected.

It said it expected to see like for like net income growth of up to 1% in 2014.

Punch's shares have fallen nearly 2% to 14.75p, having fallen as low as 13.75p. Analyst Simon French at Panmure Gordon moved from hold to sell, saying:

We are increasingly sceptical there will be any material equity value in the securitisations for existing PLC shareholders and therefore downgrade our recommendation and reiterate our 7p target price in recognition of the group's £49m investment in Matthew Clark.
